result.execSummary:
The defendant Jeffrey Howard Bagneski was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Operating w/ PAC (7th, 8th or 9th), a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(b).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
The Court sentences Mr. Bagneski to 7 years, with an Initial Term of Confinement in Prison of 5 years and the maximum time to serve on Extended Supervision of 2 years. This sentence is to commence concurrent

09/01/16: The Court and Counsel agree that Mr. Bagneski is entitled to 66 days credit.

01/27/17: Court modifies Defendants bifurcated sentence to 5 years & 130 days, with 3 years & 130 days of Initial Confinement and 2 years of extended supervision, to remain concurrent to the Defendants revocation sentences in 93CF263 (Dane Co.) and 01CF436 (Columbia Co.) but now consecutive to his revocation sentence in 04CF423 (Dodge Co.); The Court grants the Defendant 66 days of sentence credit.

*******
3/28/17: Court orders JOC be amended to reflect a sentence of 7 years Imprisonment concurrent consisting of 5 years Initial Confinement  and 2 Years Extended Supervision with 66 days credit for time served.
*******

superMiscConds.notes:
-To pay fine of $1000 + costs = $2023


09/01/16:
The Court orders that the Judgment of Convcition be ameded to indicate:
--all financial obligations, except the victim/witness surcharge is to be paid to Clerk of Courts and not to Department of Corrections

--The Court establishes a payment plan as follows: $10 per month beginning on the last day of April 2020 until March of 2022 and then $25 beginning April 2022 until paid in full

--If Mr. Bagnesski falls more than $100 behind in payments, then civil judgment is to be entered.

-No operation of a motor vehicle without a valid DL & Agent approval
-No possession or ingestion of alcohol or illegal drugs
-No presence in bars, taverns or liquor stores

-Maintain absolute sobriety
-To submit DNA Sample upon demand

Arresting Agency:  Waterloo PD

If probation, parole or extended supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of the victim(s) and government entities for the balance due.

records.addlTxt:
Case called at 1:24pm.  Clerk - CRHI.
Defendant Jeffrey Howard Bagneski in court, in custody via video from Oakhill Correctional with attorney John Paul Morgan appearing in Court.  Defendant Jeffrey Howard Bagneski in custody.  Jeffrey Martin Shock appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Wayne Stuessy also appears via video from the DOC Offender Records Office. 
Upon agreement of counsel, the Court finds the video connection to be sight and sound sufficient. 
Statement as to case and sentence status presented by Atty. Morgan, by ADA Shock and by Mr. Stuessy. 
The Court orders the JOC be amended to reflect a sentence of 7 years Imprisionment concurrent consisting of 5 years Initial Confinement and 2 years Extended Supervision with 66 days credit for time served; presents basis. 
All other terms and conditions of the last judgment of conviction are to be continued. 
Defendant indicates that he has made payments to Department of Corrections for the Victim Witness Surcharge and the DNA Surcharge.  Response presented the Court.
Recess 1:40pm.
Appeals Document Index: 2017AP000286 sent to Court of Appeals by: Cindy R Hamre

The Court orally direct the COC to Correct the JOC to overcome the defect to ensure the Court order is properly reflected on the JOC; to prepare a Supplemental Appeal Index including the Correct JOC and the transcripts filed after the preparation of the Index and distribution of the Notice of Compilation.

Case called at 9:54am [MA]
Defendant Jeffrey Howard Bagneski in court, in custody with attorney John Paul Morgan.  Monica J. Hall appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

On Defendant's Motion for Postconviction Relief:
1) Days Credit
--arguments given by ADA Hall
--arguments given by Atty. Morgan

The Court and Counsel agree that Mr. Bagneski is entitled to 66 days credit.

Upon inquiry of the Court, Atty. Morgan indicates that the Defense will object to the Court vacating the sentencing due to false information.

The Court indicates that It plans to research the authority of the Court to vacate the sentencing due to unintentional mis representation.
--Defense to file submission of topic by 9/15/16; if the State wishes to file a response they may do so by 9/29/16

2) Reduction of Fines
--the State takes no position
--arguments given by Atty. Morgan

--the Court accepts averment of the Defendant's financial situation on file
--Statement made by Mr. Bagneski
--Upon inquiry of Mr. Bagneski, the Court indicates it is a possibility to have payments made to COC after release from Extended Supervision in lieu of entry of civil judgment

The Court orders that the Judgment of Convcition be ameded to indicate:
--all financial obligations, except the victim/witness surcharge is to be paid to Clerk of Courts and not to Department of Corrections
--The Court establishes a payment plan as follows: $10 per month beginning on the last day of April 2020 until March of 2022 and then $25 beginning April 2022 until paid in full
--If Mr. Bagnesski falls more than $100 behind in payments, then civil judgment is to be entered.


recess:10:37am

Case called at 8:41 am [Clerk SH]
Defendant Jeffrey Howard Bagneski in court, in-custody, with Attorney Bradley J Jansen. ADA Brookellen Teuber appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
off-record: 8:41 - 8:43 am for Defense to complete waiver form

Court examines the Defendant as to rights, understanding & intent.  
Mr. Bagneski waives his right to Preliminary Hearing; the Court accepts this waiver and binds him over for Arraignment.
State files information; Arraignment:-service of Information admitted, reading waived-maximum penalties recited

Maximum penalties recited; Constitutional rights given; plea of "No Contest" entered; factual basis stipulated; Court finds the plea has been entered freely, voluntarily, intelligently and accepts the plea, finds Defendant guilty, and orders JOC entered.

The Court sentences Mr. Bagneski to 7 years, with an Initial Term of Confinement in Prison of 5 years and the maximum time to serve on Extended Supervision of 2 years. This sentence is to commence concurrent

The Court finds that the Defendant is not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program (Boot Camp) and the Substance Abuse Program. 
The Court gives 0 days credit for time already served.

The Court orders as conditions of Extended Supervision:
-No operation of a motor vehicle without a valid DL & Agent approval
-Maintain absolute sobriety
-No possession or ingestion of alcohol or illegal drugs
-No presence in bars, taverns or liquor stores
-To pay fine of $1000 + costs = $2023
-To pay $250 DNA Surcharge
-To submit DNA Sample upon demand

Conditions Not of Extended Supervision:
-Revocation of drivers license for 36 months
-County alcohol/drug assessment ordered
-Victim impact panel attendance
-Ignition Interlock Device requirement/restrictions for: 36 months  - Court finds the defendant indigent and eligible for cost reduction
-6 demerit points assessed
Court orders Mr. Bagneski to be booked on this matter

Felony Firearm and Voting-rights prohibitions/warnings given
Explanation of Determinate Sentence form given to the Defendant
Recess: 9:14 am
